headline: Fmr. Tesla President: Musk, Board Betting on AI
summary: Jon McNeill, co-founder of DVx Ventures and VistaShares and former Tesla president, says he's betting on Elon Musk to lead advances in robotics and aerospace, adding Musk is "especially skilled to do that." He speaks with Romaine Bostick and Katie Greifeld on "The Close."

raw.headline: Fmr. Tesla President: Musk, Board Betting on AI

headline: Wall Street indexes end higher ahead of Fed meeting; Tesla rallies
summary: STORY: The three major U.S. stock indexes closed higher on Monday with the Dow up marginally while the S&P 500 added about half of one percent and the Nasdaq rose nearly one percent. The S&P 500 and the Nasdaq hit intraday record highs.Steven Schoenfeld, CEO of MarketVector Indexes attributes the moves to the expected interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve this week.“So it seems that the markets are really factoring in a Fed cut on Wednesday and maybe even leaning toward hopes of a further cut very quickly or maybe even a bigger than expected cut on Wednesday. I think the market would be very positively surprised if the Fed cut 50 basis points, but the baseline is 25 basis points.”Traders on Monday are pricing in a 96% chance of a 25-basis-point cut at this week's meeting.Tesla also gave markets a lift, gaining 3.5% after regulatory filings revealed CEO Elon Musk had acquired nearly $1 billion worth of the electric vehicle maker's stock on Friday. Shares of Google parent Alphabet increased 4.5%, hitting a record high during the session, and racing past a $3 trillion market cap.And shares of CorveWeave added more than 7 and a half percent after the data center operator signed a deal with Nvidia that guarantees that the chipmaker will purchase any residual cloud capacity not sold to customers. The deal's initial value is $6.3 billion.

raw.headline: Wall Street indexes end higher ahead of Fed meeting; Tesla rallies
raw.summary: STORY: The three major U.S. stock indexes closed higher on Monday with the Dow up marginally while the S&P 500 added about half of one percent and the Nasdaq rose nearly one percent. The S&P 500 and the Nasdaq hit intraday record highs.Steven Schoenfeld, CEO of MarketVector Indexes attributes the moves to the expected interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve this week.“So it seems that the markets are really factoring in a Fed cut on Wednesday and maybe even leaning toward hopes of a further cut very quickly or maybe even a bigger than expected cut on Wednesday. I think the market would be very positively surprised if the Fed cut 50 basis points, but the baseline is 25 basis points.”Traders on Monday are pricing in a 96% chance of a 25-basis-point cut at this week's meeting.Tesla also gave markets a lift, gaining 3.5% after regulatory filings revealed CEO Elon Musk had acquired nearly $1 billion worth of the electric vehicle maker's stock on Friday. Shares of Google parent Alphabet increased 4.5%, hitting a record high during the session, and racing past a $3 trillion market cap.And shares of CorveWeave added more than 7 and a half percent after the data center operator signed a deal with Nvidia that guarantees that the chipmaker will purchase any residual cloud capacity not sold to customers. The deal's initial value is $6.3 billion.

headline: Trump Advisers Prepare to Target Left-Leaning Groups After Kirk Shooting
summary: WASHINGTON—The White House is moving swiftly to galvanize the outpouring of support for slain conservative activist  Charlie Kirk  into political momentum, as President Trump’s advisers weigh a slate of executive actions targeting liberal organizations.  Among the actions being discussed by the president’s team: reviewing the tax-exempt status of left-leaning nonprofit groups and targeting them with anticorruption laws, according to administration officials.  The president could begin rolling out the actions as soon as this week, officials said, part of a bid to harness support for Kirk, particularly among young voters, ahead of the midterm elections.

raw.headline: Trump Advisers Prepare to Target Left-Leaning Groups After Kirk Shooting
raw.summary: WASHINGTON—The White House is moving swiftly to galvanize the outpouring of support for slain conservative activist  Charlie Kirk  into political momentum, as President Trump’s advisers weigh a slate of executive actions targeting liberal organizations.  Among the actions being discussed by the president’s team: reviewing the tax-exempt status of left-leaning nonprofit groups and targeting them with anticorruption laws, according to administration officials.  The president could begin rolling out the actions as soon as this week, officials said, part of a bid to harness support for Kirk, particularly among young voters, ahead of the midterm elections.

headline: Tesla jumps after Musk buys shares worth $1 billion
summary: STORY: Tesla shares rose as much as 7.5% Monday morning after a regulatory filing showed that CEO Elon Musk bought nearly $1 billion worth of the electric-vehicle maker's stock.The purchase reinforces Musk's push for greater control over the company, which is racing to meet its ambitious targets on robotaxis, artificial intelligence and robotics as it looks to pivot from an EV maker to a tech leader. As of December, Musk held a roughly 13% stake in Tesla, according to LSEG data.Musk has consistently demanded a bigger stake and increased voting power at Tesla.He has also threatened to build AI and robotics products outside of Tesla if he cannot get 25% voting power.Earlier this month, Tesla's board proposed a $1 trillion compensation plan for Musk, in a huge vote of confidence for Musk's leadership from the board, even as the company stumbles amid heated competition and cooling EV demand.On Friday, board chair Robyn Denholm dismissed concerns that Musk's political activity had hurt sales and said the billionaire was back "front and center" at the company after several months at the White House.Musk's political activity and public clashes with President Donald Trump had stirred worries among investors about distractions and potential lost sales, which had weighed on the company's stock this year.

raw.headline: Tesla jumps after Musk buys shares worth $1 billion
raw.summary: STORY: Tesla shares rose as much as 7.5% Monday morning after a regulatory filing showed that CEO Elon Musk bought nearly $1 billion worth of the electric-vehicle maker's stock.The purchase reinforces Musk's push for greater control over the company, which is racing to meet its ambitious targets on robotaxis, artificial intelligence and robotics as it looks to pivot from an EV maker to a tech leader. As of December, Musk held a roughly 13% stake in Tesla, according to LSEG data.Musk has consistently demanded a bigger stake and increased voting power at Tesla.He has also threatened to build AI and robotics products outside of Tesla if he cannot get 25% voting power.Earlier this month, Tesla's board proposed a $1 trillion compensation plan for Musk, in a huge vote of confidence for Musk's leadership from the board, even as the company stumbles amid heated competition and cooling EV demand.On Friday, board chair Robyn Denholm dismissed concerns that Musk's political activity had hurt sales and said the billionaire was back "front and center" at the company after several months at the White House.Musk's political activity and public clashes with President Donald Trump had stirred worries among investors about distractions and potential lost sales, which had weighed on the company's stock this year.

headline: Musk’s $1 billion Tesla stock buy sends shares up for the year
summary: The purchase coincided with Tesla Chair Robyn Denholm speaking with reporters about the merits of awarding Musk around $1 trillion worth of stock if the company achieves a series of ambitious market value and performance milestones.  Tesla shares jumped 6.2% at 9:30 a.m. in New York.  Musk, 54, last bought Tesla stock in the open market in February 2020, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

raw.headline: Elon Musk Buys $1 Billion Worth of Tesla Stock
raw.summary: Elon Musk bought $1 billion in Tesla stock though a revocable trust on Friday. That's when Bloomberg spoke to Tesla's Chair Robyn Denholm who said Musk is the right leader for the company. Bloomberg's Ed Ludlow reports.

headline: Fed meeting, Tesla stock, US-China trade talks: 3 Things
summary: US stock futures (ES=F, NQ=F, YM=F) are moving in positive territory ahead of the Federal Reserve's September FOMC meeting this Wednesday, at which Wall Street expects officials to cut interest rates. Tesla (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk reported that he bought $1 billion worth of stock in the EV developer last week. US and Chinese officials have reentered trade negotiations, with TikTok and Nvidia (NVDA) being at the forefront of talks between regulators. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

headline: Wall Street Lunch: Trump Proposes Shift To Semiannual Earnings
summary: President Donald Trump said companies should not be forced to report earnings on a quarterly basis and should switch to posting numbers on a six-month basis.

headline: Tesla, Opendoor, Labubu: Trending Stocks
summary: Elon Musk triggers a Tesla (TSLA) price surge after purchasing $1 billion worth of shares in the company, Pop Mart (9992.HK) takes a downturn as the Labubu craze begins to subside, and Opendoor (OPEN) continues with its wild fluctuations as key founders rejoined the board of the company. For more live coverage of markets watch the full episode of Market Sunrise and head to Yahoo Finance.

headline: International Land Alliance Launches BOXABL at Cabo Oasis
summary: Affordable Tesla-Powered BOXABL Tiny Homes Coming to Cabo Oasis Expanding Flagship Development SAN DIEGO, Sept. 15, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- International Land Alliance, Inc. headline: Tesla Shares Leap After Musk Makes $1 Billion Stock Purchase
summary: Shares in Tesla (TSLA) jumped in premarket trading after Elon Musk disclosed his first purchase of the stock in the open market since February 2020. Tesla’s CEO purchased more than 2.5 million shares in the company on Friday, totaling around $1 billion, according to a regulatory filing on Monday.
